title: Sample Selection via Contrastive Fragmentation for Noisy Label Regression
author: Chris Dongjoo Kim (Seoul National University), Sangwoo Moon (Seoul National University), Jihwan Moon (Seoul National University), Dongyeon Woo (Seoul National University), Gunhee Kim (Seoul National University, LG AI Research), ...
relevance_why: The proposed ConFrag framework could influence audio-related generative models by improving how noisy labels in datasets are managed, which can be applied to tasks like music generation or audio restoration.
background: The research addresses how to effectively manage noisy labels in regression tasks, which is common in real-world datasets, via a new framework that enhances sample selection.
contribution: This paper introduces the Contrastive Fragmentation (ConFrag) framework to solve the issues posed by noisy labels in regression, achieving improved selection of clean samples and enhanced predictive performance.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods for handling noisy labels have primarily focused on classification settings, often requiring knowledge of noise rates or shown performance limitations in regression contexts.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work uniquely transforms the regression problem into multiple binary classifications guided by the contrastive fragment pairs, allowing more robust training without knowing the noise rate.

key_innovation: The ConFrag framework leverages the natural relationships between labels and features by employing contrastive pairs to identify and select clean data samples effectively.
real_world_impact: The framework can lead to more accurate predictive models in various applications, such as finance or medicine, by better handling erroneous labels in training datasets.
limitations: The proposed method relies on the assumption that continuous labels are available and does not explicitly handle cases of extreme label noise.

new_terms.contrastive fragment pairs: **Contrastive fragment pairs** refer to pairs of data fragments that are significantly different in label space, used to improve the generalization of models against noisy labels during training.

open_sourcing: The code is available at https://github.com/cdjkim/ConFrag
